message:
Hiii, I have been digging lately for software engineer salaries and software hourly rates. 
I can easily get the statistics of salaries and rates for different programming languages and platforms worldwide but, What about Egypt ?

For a free lancer developer (back-end, web, mobile or software in general) how much should he charge for a development hour in Egypt?
Is it the same as freelance websites (ex. upwork, Freelancer or toptal) ?

In a discussion with a software engineer he told me that pricing should be as follows:
A fresh software engineer gets about 4500 LE as a start(as far as I can remember that was a year ago )
divided by 160 hours per month (4 weeks x 5 days x 8 hours)
results in 28.125 LE per hour

But this is way less than the minimum allowed by upwork (min of 3$ = 3*15.79 = 47.37 LE)!!! 
Actually beginner free lancers charge at 5$ (78.95 LE) and 10$!!

He said that I should not be comparing the prices here In Egypt to upwork!

I searched in vain, Most Arabic resources discussing salaries and rates are not so useful and have no mention of prices in Egypt
http://www.badwi.com/blog/?p=53

The only useful resource I could find is a survey about Egyptian salaries that was posted here a few month ago 
https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1FY7Y00vn5rkpvq2mJVZ7JO2ThJttzXjsJBdJsqBHwTE/edit#gid=0

I understand that hourly rates vary by many factors (experience, language, tools etc) but, I'm only interested in how to determine the the minimum and average rate in general.

So should we follow the freelance website prices ? How Egyptian software companies charge clients ? Do we consider Dollar price into out calculations ? Is there any other way of determining the cost of software ?

Another question, 
For a fresh graduate software engineer in Egypt how can I decide if I'm being offered a fair salary when I cant find such available statistics?

data.message: I think u can't compare freelancing websites to us for some reasons .. the most important is that people offering jobs there from western countries will probably use their websites in an environment where the profits will be higher, by the same ratio, than the profits made by Egyptian startups and companies .. so for example a way to compare can be the minimum wage in US vs the average salary of regular junior developer in US against the Egyptian minimum wage to predict the Egyptian average salary .. I'm not sure that this is the right way but it's theoretically valid.

There are several ways to calculate the fee structure but at the end of the day, it's a negotiating game. 

For the person hiring, you look at how much it would cost you to hire someone else to so the job, and start taking offers. That could be hiring full time employee, or contracting a company for a fixed price with set deliverables. 

As for the person doing the work, i think accepting an offer that is simply an hourly rate of a full time job is the worst thing they can do. Typically a freelancer should either charge you a price that is near your other offers (if we are talking about a fixed budget), or it should be an the hourly rate of a full time salary TIMES a factor (minimum 1.5). The employer can't pay the lower cost of a full time salary rate without the full time employment commitment. It's simply not fair. The freelance developer doesn't have the job security a fulltime job offers, yet can offer you a lower cost and more flexibility. 

What really matters here is their ability to deliver quality work that would have cost you multiple times more had you hired a company. Depending on what you want and their portfolio, either options could be better.

As far as I know a lot of Egyptian startups are actually doing their business for foreign clients which pay them in USD or Euro and those startups will still pay you in Egyptian currency and maybe even far below the decent average of a software engineer because why not, you know
